It based on native js dates so you can use this Date Picker with any date library you want.

default.title: Basic usage
default.text: By default, use this component with v-model.

mode.title: Mode
mode.text: You can use date picker in three different ways. By default date picker uses `auto` mode. This means that `mode` will be chosen based on `modelValue`. There is three modes: `single`, `multiple` and `range`. Different modes require different model values.

stateful.title: Stateful
stateful.text: Date picker can be stateful. Initial value will be undefined, but user can change it.

firstWeekday.title: First day of the week
firstWeekday.text: If you want to always use Monday as the first day of the week, you can set this prop in GlobalConfig.

weekends.title: Weekends
weekends.text: You can highlight weekends using `highlight-weekends` prop. Also, you can set your own weekends using `weekends` function.

otherMonths.title: Other month days
otherMonths.text: You can show days of other months using `show-other-months` prop instead of blank cells in calendar.

slots.title: Slots
slots.text: For now, we don't support localization using one prop. But you have opportunity to localize it by yourself using slots.

view.title: View
view.text: You can set specific view for date picker. With `view` prop you can define how date picker will displayed, year and month that will be shown.

type.title: Type
type.text: If you want allow user to pick only month or year, you can make it using `type` prop.

disabledDates.title: Disable dates
disabledDates.text: You can disable some specific days, month or year using `allowedDays`, `allowedMonth` or `allowedYear` props.

colors.title: Colors
colors.text: You can change colors using CSS variables for deeper customization, but also you can simple change colors using props.

disabled.title: Disabled
disabled.text: Disabled picker that can be used in forms.

dateInput.title: Date Input
dateInput.description: Date Input component is a combination of Date Picker and Input components. You can find usage examples using following links:

resetOnClose.title: Reset on close
resetOnClose.text: There is a prop `resetOnClose` for range mode. If user selected incomplete range and closed dropdown, then used last complete value.

isOpen.title: IsOpen
isOpen.text: IsOpen prop allows you to force show dropdown as opened.

formatting.title: Formatting
formatting.text: You can pass the format function to VaDateInput which will format input text like you want to. This way you can use any format that you want. For example, you can use [date-fns](https://date-fns.org/v2.23.0/docs/format)[[target=_blank]].

input.title: Input date
input.text: You can allow user to input text from keyboard. You need to set readonly prop as true. You can pass the parse function to VaDateInput which will parse input text like you want to. This way you can use any format that you want. For example, you can use [date-fns](https://date-fns.org/v2.23.0/docs/format)[[target=_blank]] to parse date string. By default we parse this input using standard `Date.parse` method.

advancedFormatting.title: Advanced formatting
advancedFormatting.text: If you need specific format for multiple or range modes you can use.

formattingGlobalConfig.text: You can easily use your format functions for all VaDateInputs using [Global Config](/services/components-config) feature.

validation.title: Validation
validation.text: Validation works the same way as `VaInput` validation, except rules functions should accept `Date` instead of `string`.

buttonGroup.title: Button Group
buttonGroup.summaryText: It is a special component that wraps buttons and applies special styles to them.

default.title: Basic usage
default.text: By default, you need to wrap your buttons with a `va-button-group` component.

colors.title: Colors
colors.text: Component provides color to each child button.

gradient.title: Gradient
gradient.text: It’s used to apply a gradient style to a background.

icons.title: Icons
icons.text: Looks good with icons provided to buttons.

buttonToggle.title: Button Toggle
buttonToggle.summaryText: The button is used to switch between different values.

default.title: Basic usage
default.text: By default, an object with parameters and a v-model is to be passed.

colors.title: Colors
colors.text: Applies color presets and HEX colors.

toggleColor.title: Toggler color
toggleColor.text: Use `toggle-color` prop to set the color of the active button.

sizes.title: Sizes
sizes.text: You can provide size presets to the component.

styles.title: Styles
styles.text: You can set button styles to the component.

appBar.title: App bar
appBar.summaryText: The app bar component is a part of a website’s navigation and it’s an alternative to the header element in apps.

default.title: Basic usage
default.text: By default, a `va-app-bar` needs a parent element with relative position.

color.title: Color
color.text: You can set a background color and gradient of the component with `color` and `gradient` props.

bottom.title: Bottom
bottom.text: You can make app bar sit at the bottom of the screen with `bottom` prop.

hide.title: Hide
hide.text: `hide-on-scroll` allows you to hide app bar when you scroll away. You need to define `target`.

shadow.title: Shadow
shadow.text: You can set a shadow with `shadow-on-scroll` prop. You need to define `target`.

innerLoading.title: Inner Loading
innerLoading.summaryText: You can handle the loading state of the wrapped component by using the `va-inner-loading` component.

default.title: Basic usage
default.text: By default wrap a component in `va-inner-loading` with a `loading` property.

color.title: Color
color.text: You can change the color of the icon.

size.title: Size
size.text: Supports the ability to resize the icon.

icon.title: Icon
icon.text: You can change the loading icon.

installation.title: Installation
installation.description: You can create a new project or integrate Vuestic UI into an existing application. The installation process is mostly the same for both cases: you can either *install Vuestic UI manually* or use specifically designed *Vue CLI plugin*. Both ways provide you with a **full tree-shaking support**. Choose the one that fits your needs the most.

fonts.title: Assets installation
fonts.description: By default Vuestic UI uses `Source Sans Pro` and `Material Icons` fonts. You should manually add them into your project. In order to do so you can either:
fonts.htmlExampleTitle: include fonts directly in your `index.html`'s `<head>` element
fonts.cssExampleTitle: or include them in your CSS

quickStart.title: Modify your application's entry point
quickStart.description: Import both the styles and the plugin into your entry file. The plugin is used to automatically register all the components, directives and other stuff globally. If you don't want to register everything globally then check out the tree-shaking section below.

cli.title: Vue CLI installation
cli.description: Recommended way to install Vuestic UI is using the Vue CLI plugin. Works fine with vite or webpack.
cli.attention: Installing Vuestic UI via the plugin would modify your `package.json` and `main.(js`|`ts)` files, so make sure you’ve committed your code before proceeding to avoid data loss.
cli.prepare: First, make sure you've got [Vue CLI](https://cli.vuejs.org/guide/installation.html)[[target=_blank]] installed globally:
cli.upgrade: Notice also that the minimum supported version of Vue CLI is v4.0.0. In case you've got an older version installed, please, consider [upgrading](https://cli.vuejs.org/migrating-from-v3/#migrating-from-v3)[[target=_blank]] it.
cli.codeAnnotation: If everything's fine then you can finally install the plugin with the following command (**don't forget to commit**):

treeShaking.title: Tree shaking
treeShaking.description: If you plan to use only several components in your application and thus reduce the size of your bundle, you can use the Vuestic ESM build. Webpack (vue-cli) and Vite do that automatically.

example.title: First, you don't need to use `VuesticPlugin` since it registers all the `vuestic` components globally. Instead, you can import specific components from the `vuestic-ui` package.
example.footer: Alternatively, you can import them directly in your `.vue` files.

plugins.title: In such a case you'd also have to register Vuestic plugins by yourself. We recommend to use all of them:
plugins.GlobalConfigPlugin: GlobalConfigPlugin - used for `VaConfig` component and global props reassignment. [Read more](/services/global-config).
plugins.ColorHelpersPlugin: ColorHelpersPlugin - used to create reactive CSS variables. Requires `GlobalConfigPlugin`. [Read more](/services/colors-config).

example.title: All of these plugins are also available through the `VuesticPluginsWithoutComponents`:

attention.cssLoader:
As all components' code is separated, you may need a CSS loader to load component-specific CSS.
But you probably already have one.

manual.title: Manual installation
manual.subtitle: If you decide to install Vuestic UI manually, all you need to do is to install a NPM package, a couple of other necessary assets (such as fonts and CSS styles) and slightly modify your application's entry point (most probably `index.js` or `main.js`, depending on your setup).
manual.prerequisites: But first, make sure you've got all the following prerequisites installed:
manual.afterCheck: After checking the prerequisites, install Vuestic UI via npm or yarn:

roadmap.title: Vuestic UI Roadmap
roadmap.description: Our team is constantly improving the existing code base and adding new features that help building applications even easier.

inDevelopment.title: In development
inDevelopment.description: The following releases are currently being developed:

1-4.title: [v1.4](https://github.com/epicmaxco/vuestic-ui/milestone/7)
1-4.description:
* Carousel component. 
 * Stepper component. 
 * Nuxt support.

1-3.title: [v1.3](https://github.com/epicmaxco/vuestic-ui/releases/tag/v1.3.0)
1-3.description:
* CSS only table. 
 * Data Table component. 
 * Data Table theme for [AG grid](https://www.ag-grid.com/)[[target=_blank]].

1-2.title: [v1.2](https://github.com/epicmaxco/vuestic-ui/releases/tag/v1.2.1)
1-2.description:
* Date Input component. 
 * Date Picker component. 
 * Tree shaking (allows to import only components you need, reducing bundle size).

1-1.title: [v1.1](https://github.com/epicmaxco/vuestic-ui/releases/tag/v1.1.0)
1-1.description:
* SSR support (vite). 
 * Remove medium-editor wrapper. 
 * Russian translation. 
 * Reduce bundle size (482KB).

1-0.title: [v1.0](https://github.com/epicmaxco/vuestic-ui/tree/v1.0.0)
1-0.description:
Starting point of vuestic-ui. 
 * Reworked and added multiple components. 
 * Added proper documentation.

0-1.title: [v0.1](https://github.com/epicmaxco/vuestic-ui/tree/1.0.0-alpha.0)
0-1.description: Not even alpha, we've just split components from [vuestic-admin](https://github.com/epicmaxco/vuestic-admin)[[target=_blank]] into separate repository to simplify updates.

longTimeSupport.title: Long time support
longTimeSupport.description: The following versions have continued maintenance for backwards compatible fixes, major bugs, and security vulnerabilities.

archive.title: Archive
archive.description: The following releases are old and unsupported minor and major versions:

accessibilityGuide.title: Accessibility
accessibilityGuide.description: Vuestic UI components support keyboard interactions for all mouse-based actions and utilize HTML5 semantic elements where applicable.

keyboardInteractions.title: Keyboard accessible
keyboardInteractions.description: All the interactive elements on your page (e.g. text boxes, buttons, etc.) can be accessed with the keyboard. That means you should be able to focus them by using Tab and Shift+Tab keys.

configurationGuide.title: Configuration
configurationGuide.description: Vuestic UI comes with a convenient mechanism that allows for a deep icons, components, and colors customization.

colors.title: Color themes
colors.description: You can easily modify the colors used by Vuestic UI components (and even add custom ones):

icons.title: Icon fonts
icons.description: By default Vuestic UI uses **material icons**, so make sure to install the package:
icons.subtitle: Using custom icons
icons.subDescription: With Icons Config you can use any icon font you'd like by simply transforming the icon names to respective props.

components.title: Components config
components.intro: If you want to set global defaults for Vuestic components — we've got a config for that either!
components.description: Let’s say you want all of your buttons to be `outline` and `small` to match your design, but by default that's not the case:
components.action: To solve that problem edit to `main.js` file the following way:
components.result: Now all of your buttons by default will look like this:
components.example: You can configure any prop for any Vuestic UI component in such a manner.
components.more: In case your customization runs deeper consider [overriding CSS variables](/styles/css-variables#overriding) or even directly the `.class`' properties (components use BEM-notation so it should be easy to figure out which selector to address with the help of standard dev-tooling).

browserSupport.title: Browser Support
browserSupport.description: We design Vuestic UI to be future proof. That's why we support modern browsers, but some old browsers, such as IE had to go, sorry. That decision was influenced by [dropped support in Vue 3](https://github.com/vuejs/rfcs/discussions/296)[[target=_blank]] and [falling usage rate](https://caniuse.com/usage-table)[[target=_blank]].

overview.title: What is Vuestic UI
overview.description: We’ve designed the framework in such a way that it satisfies the most sophisticated design fantasies and allows you to implement them.
overview.featureRich: Contains a **50+ feature-rich components** that can be used in any design solution
overview.configurable: Allows **to configure components** globally via config and CSS variables
overview.responsive: Fully **responsive** and **supports modern browsers** (no IE11, sorry)

translation.title: Translation
translation.description: For the moment being we only provide translations for the main documentation pages (such as Contribution, Getting Started, etc.). The actual translation-strings could be found at `packages/docs/locales`. Currently there are no translations available for the components' docs. After you finish working on a translation for some page, please, do not forget to update its status to `full` in the `locales/index.ts` file. Here's the current languages-support state:

sync.title: Synchronizing locale files
sync.description: You can sync the locale files with the following command (the source file is `en.json`):

unused.title: Searching unused translations
unused.description: You can search unused translations with the following command:

missed.title: Searching missed translations
missed.description: You can search missed translations with the following command:

code.title: Translations inside code blocks
code.description: It's important to see a translated text instead of vue-i18n function inside a code block, so, we created some helpers that allow us to translate the text inside code blocks like we translate it inside a vue templates.
code.basicText: Just pass the vue-i18n function inside a code and the helper will return a translated text wrapped inside brackets.
code.mustacheText: Wrap the vue-i18n function inside double curly braces and the helper will return just a translated text.

table.title: Tables
table.summaryText: You can use plain `<table>`s with the `.va-table` class that would apply Vuestic-theme styles to them.

otherTables.text: If you want more functional solutions, use our data-table component or our theme for AG-Grid:

default.title: Basic usage
default.text: Add the `.va-table` class to the `<table>` element.

hoverable.title: Hoverable
hoverable.text: Highlight hovered rows with additional `.va-table--hoverable` class.

striped.title: Striped
striped.text: The `.va-table--striped` class colorizes each even row of the table.

clickable.title: Clickable
clickable.text: Change the cursor to `pointer` when hovering rows by adding the `.va-table--clickable` class

guide.title: Contribution guide
guide.description: This guide describes the possible ways in which you can become a part of the ongoing development of Vuestic UI. We are really excited that you are interested in helping us make Vuestic better!

description.localBranches: The `master` branch keeps the latest stable release plus potentially some cherry-picked hotfixes. All the development should be conducted in local branches (fork of the project).
description.dontSubmitToMaster: **Do not submit PRs against the `master` branch.** Use the `develop` one instead.
description.checkoutFeat: Checkout a `feat/*` branch from the `develop`, then create a pull request to `develop`.
description.multipleSmallCommits: It's OK to have multiple small commits as you work on your PR - we will let GitHub automatically squash them into a single one before merging.
description.fixBugSteps:
If fixing a bug:
  * If you are resolving a certain issue, add `close #<xxx>[,#<yyy>]` (<xxx>, <yyy> is the related issues' ids) into the PR's description so that GitHub could [automatically close](https://docs.github.com/en/github/managing-your-work-on-github/linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue#linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue-using-a-keyword)[[target=_blank]] the related issue(s) as soon as the respective commits are merged into the `master` branch (i.e. as soon as a new version of Vuestic UI is out).
  * Provide detailed description of the bug inside the PR in case the bug is not arranged in the form of a separate issue.

branches.title: Branches
branches.publicBranches:
Public branches (**epicmax/vuestic-ui**):
  * `master` - releases and hotfixes only. Do not submit PR's to `master`!
  * `develop` - main development branch.
branches.localBranches:
Local branches
  * For local branches prepend your messages with `feat/` (e.g. for a tabs-related fix it would be `feat/fix-tabs`). This is necessary to keep local branches visually separated from the public ones.

forCoreContributors.title: For the core contributors
forCoreContributors.linkPr: Always link a PR to its related issue (via `close #123`).
forCoreContributors.assignYourself: When you start working on a task - please self-assign the related issue. We don't want a lot of people working simultaneously on the same thing (except when intentional).
forCoreContributors.smallIssues: For small issues you may push to the `develop` branch directly while adding `close #123` to the commit message.
forCoreContributors.singlePrPerIssue: Create a single PR for one issue. If we have several PRs - move all the code into a single PR and close the rest. If one PR covers several issues - either split it in several PRs or mark one of the issues as duplicate.
forCoreContributors.onePersonPerIssue: Make sure to assign an issue to only a single person.
forCoreContributors.beProactive: Be proactive. If you think something is wrong - create an issue or discuss.
forCoreContributors.workInBook: If you work on UI components - work in the book environment (`yarn serve:book`). We want to keep global stuff out of components.

beforeReleaseWorkflow.title: Before release workflow
beforeReleaseWorkflow.description: Update packages' versions. Update the lock files (for both `npm` and `yarn`)

globalConfig.title: Global config
globalConfig.subtitle: With the help of Global config one can configure default values for colors, icons and components' props.
globalConfig.structure: Global config consists of `icons`, `colors`, `components` and `componentsAll` configs.
globalConfig.setupExampleTitle: You can provide a custom config as the second argument when registering the `VuesticPlugin`:
globalConfig.reactiveUpdateExampleTitle: Or you can update the configuration partially at the runtime:
globalConfig.reactiveSetExampleTitle: Alternatively, you can substitute the whole configuration object at the runtime with another one:
globalConfig.useInRuntime: The global configuration object might be made reactive:

api.icons: Used to configure icon fonts and aliases.
api.components: Used to globally overwrite props of specific components.
api.componentsAll: Used to globally set props for all components. If there are no other source of props.
api.colors: Used to define theme colors that components make use of. Here you can redefine default Vuestic-theme colors.

iconsConfig.title: Icons config
iconsConfig.about: By default Vuestic UI uses [Material Design icons](https://fonts.google.com/icons)[[target=_blank]]. If you want to use other font libraries you can configure `VaIcon` to use them.
iconsConfig.readBeforeStart: Find out more about the VaIcon component

problem.definition: There is a problem with icon libraries however: they usually use different interfaces to render icons.
problem.materialIcons: For example Material Icons wants us to set `material-icons` class and provide icon name inside the `span` tag.
problem.fontAwesome: If we want to use FontAwesome5 we need to provide the `fas` class and then another one with the name of the icon (prefixed with `fa-` on the `i` tag).
problem.summary: With Icons config we can instead provide an icon name using any style that fits our needs the best. We only need to configure how an icon for with the provided name will be rendered once.

fonts.title: Fonts
fonts.about: We want to use the `<va-icon name='icon-name' />` pattern. We can setup a config for a specific icon name pattern. In that config we provide an icon class, contents (innerHTML) or a Vue component relative to icon name.

fontNamePattern.title: Font name pattern
fontNamePattern.about: Font name pattern is similar to vue dynamic routes. We can use dynamic segments to dynamically generate the icon class, content and props. Dynamic segments should be written in curly brackets.

example.title: Example fonts config
example.about: Let`s take a look at some examples
example.explain: Below we can see how the icons would be transformed

aliases.title: Aliases
aliases.about: To make code simpler we can use aliases. Alias has a `to` prop which would change the name of a given icon to the value of `to` and look for an appropriate font config. All the props from resolved font would be applied to that icon if they were not defined in alias config.

example.title: Example aliases config
example.about: Below we can see how the icons would be transformed
example.explain: As you can see alias config is more important than font config. And `va-icon` props take precedence over both.

setup.title: Let's build our config
setup.about: We need to update icons config in our global config. Icons config is a flat array with Vuestic default font and aliases. We can use the `createIconsConfig()` helper to create a new config with Vuestic defaults and our custom fonts and aliases merged together. For example:

api.title: Icon config API
api.name: String or regex. Can be a string with dynamic segment or regex to use this config as font.
api.iconClass: Class that will be applied to the icon. Can be a string or a function that accepts dynamic segment value and returns a string.
api.content: Content that will be inside the icon. Can be a string or a function that accepts dynamic segment value and returns a string.
api.component: VueComponent that will be used instead of a tag.
api.componentProps: Props that will be bound to `component`. Can be an object or a function that accepts dynamic segment value and returns an object.
api.to: Here you can define name of a config which values will be merged to this config
api.tag: A tag to render icon with. By default - `i`
api.color: Sets the CSS `color` property to a given value
api.rotation: Rotates the icon by specified angle (in degrees)
api.spin: Applies the spin animation to the icon

componentsConfig.title: Components config
componentsConfig.subtitle: Component config allows you to override default props' values for any Vuestic component. It is an object where the keys are component names and the values are prop-value pairs you want to overwrite. For example:
componentsConfig.demoTitle: The example below allows you to change styling of all the buttons for the whole Vuestic Documentation site. Feel free to navigate to Button docs page and take a look at the updated examples.

componentsAll.title: All components config
componentsAll.subtitle: You could use `componentsAll` global config property to set prop values for all components at once. It will be applied if there are no other source of prop value. For example:
componentsAll.description: These prop values will be used as default values if prop is not set somewhere else (inside the component or inside other configs).

vaConfig.title: Scoped config
vaConfig.subtitle: You can use the `<va-config>` component to overwrite the default props' values for the components inside that tag. Take a look at the demo below:
vaConfig.explain: Look at the code. In this demo we have changed the default color for all the `VaButton`s and `VaIcons`s inside the `VaConfig`. We also pass a different value to the third button's `color` prop (direct component's prop takes precedence over the one specified on the `VaConfig`).

defaultSizes.title: Default sizes
defaultSizes.description: If you would like to set default sizes for the component you could use sizesConfig property. Feel free to check the example below:

api.title: Component config service API
api.ComponentConfig: Object where the keys are Vuestic component names and the values are the component's new default props.
api.ComponentsAllConfig: Object where the keys are prop names and the values are the prop's new default values. Will be applied if there are no other source of prop value.

colorsConfig.title: Colors config
colorsConfig.about: You can personalize colors that are used in your app. The colors used by Vuestic components may be redefined dynamically. You can also add your own colors that you intend to use frequently in your app.

example.about: For example, you can change the `primary` color that is used by almost all Vuestic components.
example.demo: Pick a different primary color below and notice how the colors are changing all over the page.

reactivity.subtitle: Reactivity
reactivity.about: As you can see, methods like `getColor`, `getColors` don’t return `Proxy`. If you want to use color as reactive Proxy, use computed properties like in the example above.

otherServices.subtitle: Colors config with other services
otherServices.components: You can use your custom colors in Components config.
otherServices.icons: As well as in Icons config.
otherServices.css: CSS-variables do also respect the color config and dynamically change their values!

api.title: Icon config service API
api.ColorConfig: An object where the keys are the color names and the values are valid CSS colors.
api.setColors: Used to merge new colors into config or update existing colors.
api.getBoxShadowColor: Return a color that is appropriate to be used for the `box-shadow`.
api.getHoverColor: Return a color that you can use as a `hover` color.
api.getFocusColor: Return a color that you can use as a `focus` color.
api.getGradientBackground: Return a gradient-color that you can use as a `background-image` CSS property's value.

cssVariables.title: Css Variables
cssVariables.description: Vuestic UI extracts crucial CSS styles in the form of [CSS variables (custom properties)](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/Using_CSS_custom_properties)[[target=_blank]]. No need to install any loaders or additional packages to override components' styling. Instead, you can deeply customize components' visuals using the following simple syntax.

convention.title: Convention
convention.description: Vuestic UI uses the following convention to organize CSS Variables for the sake of convenience:
convention.unnecessary: is unnecessary part needed only for specific cases.
convention.componentName: component name started with va- prefix.
convention.state: state of elements or its preset.
convention.nestedElement: some element that can be nested in root component.
convention.groupOfElements: group or type of HTML elements.

overriding.title: Overriding
overriding.description: No additional tooling is needed. Just create a CSS file (like `overrides.css`), import it into your `main.js` and start redefining the variables as you do with any other CSS properties:

default.title: Default
default.text: You can use left, center and right slots to pass items to navbar.

colors.title: Colors
colors.text: By default navbar uses `secondary` color. You can pass `color` props to change navbar background color. Also, text color depends on navbar background color. But you can pass own color if you want.

shape.title: Shape
shape.text: You can add the shape to navbar background. Shape color will be taken automatic from `color` prop.

buttonDropdown.title: Button Dropdown
buttonDropdown.summaryText: This is a button that displays drop-down content when clicked.

default.title: Basic usage
default.text: By default, wrap your content in `va-button-dropdown` component.

split.title: Split
split.text: You can split the button in two.

styles.title: Styles
styles.text: You can use the same styles as in `va-button`.

icons.title: Icons
icons.text: You can set the dropdown icon.

clickInside.title: Click inside
clickInside.text: You could set the dropdown to be closed or not after clicking on its content.

popover.title: Popover
popover.summaryText: A `va-popover` can be used to display some text on top of the component.

default.title: Basic usage
default.text: Wrap your component in a `va-popover` tag and provide a `message` property with text.

color.title: Color
color.text: You can set different background colors to the component.

placement.title: Placement
placement.text: A component can be set in a different position. Use a position property to set it: `top`, `left`, `right` and `bottom` are available.

icon.title: Icon
icon.text: You can set an icon to the component.

title.title: Title
title.text: You can set a title to the popover.

trigger.title: Trigger
trigger.text: Events triggering the popover separated with spaces: `hover`, `click` or `focus`.

typography.title: Typography
typography.description: To improve your application's UX, make sure to style the typography the way that would match the rest of the Vuestic-UI-based look and feel.

ag-grid.title: AG Grid Theme
ag-grid.description: If you need more flexible customization of the display of tables, we recommend using the [AG Grid](https://www.ag-grid.com/vue-data-grid/getting-started)[[target=_blank]] library. Vuestic UI provides a ready-made style theme for this library.

otherTables.text: Also, we provide styles for HTML Table and have own data-table component:

ag-grid.dependencies: To start using AG Grid, install the dependencies in your project.
ag-grid.importStyles: Then import the stylesheet that define the grid "structure" and apply the `ag-theme-vuestic` theme on the grid component.

default.title: Default usage
default.text: To render a vuestic-style table correctly, you must provide the table dimensions (`width` and `height`), dataset (`rowData`) and column definitions (` columnDefs`) according to this dataset.

styles.title: Styles
styles.text: The theme supports the use of the classes `ag-theme-vuestic--striped` to highlight each even row of the table and` ag-theme-vuestic--hoverable` to highlight a line on hover.

filter.title: Filters and sorting
filter.text: You can provide some options for the definition object to enable filtering and sorting.

pinning.title: Rows pinning
pinning.text: To pin rows at the top or bottom, simply provide an array of rows for the `pinnedTopRowData` and `pinnedBottomRowData` properties.

pagination.title: Pagination
pagination.text: You can enable pagination for the table by providing the required properties.

editable.title: Cell editing
editable.text: Provide `editable` property to column definition and then double click or press Enter on selected cell to enable editing mode.

ag-grid.attention: Vuestic-UI provides styles for AG-Grid Community and doesn't change any functional. For more examples and differences between Community and Enterprise versions visit the official [AG-Grid documentation page](https://www.ag-grid.com/vue-data-grid/column-properties/)[[target=_blank]].

dataTable.title: Data table
dataTable.description: The `va-data-table` component is used for displaying tabular data. Features include sorting, searching, pagination, row selection, ability to add additional row(s) to table header (`<thead>`), body (`<tbody>`) or footer (`<tfoot>`) and other functions.

otherTables.text: Also, we provide styles for HTML Table and have own theme for AG-Grid:

default.title: Basic usage
default.text: The standard `va-data-table` will by default render your data as simple rows.

slots.title: Slots
text: Slots allow you to control the display of data and their views in different parts of the table. The examples below demonstrate some of these slots and what you can do with each of them.
**Using custom slots**. Custom slots (*username*, *street* and *company name*) display certain data.
**Showing header, body and footer's prepend and append static rows**. For added (prepended and appended) static rows an additional `className` with a background color is set.
**Using `colgroup` slot to set specific attributes to columns**. For last column an additional `className` with a background color is set.

filtering.title: Filtering
filtering.text:
`va-data-table` allows to apply a single filter for the entire table with the `filter` prop. To use a custom filtering function provide the `va-data-table` with the `filter-method` prop.

The following example shows the use of a custom filtering function (which looks for the exact match rather than the standard one which checks for substring-inclusion) when the respective checkbox is checked.

sorting.title: Sorting
sorting.text:
You can specify which columns should be sortable by providing a column definition object (see the `columns` prop below) with the `sortable: true` field. Making a column sortable means allowing to click the column's header to toggle the sorting by that column's values.

You can also provide a custom sorting function for a given column using the `sortingFn` field on the column definition object: `sortingFn: (a: any, b: any) => number`. The function takes two cells' initial values (a, b) (**note: initial values** (i.e. in the form the user provided them, rather than stringified)) and must return a number (-1, 0, +1) indicating whether the two rows should be swapped the places or not. See the standard JS's [Array.prototype.sort](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/sort)[[target=_blank]] for details. If you want to runtime-disable the custom function and start making use of the built-in one, pass the `undefined` to the `sortingFn`.

`va-data-table` also optionally accepts the `sort-by` and the `sorting-order` modeled props, which allow users to change sorting settings from-outside and to model the changes introduced to the table's sorting by interacting with the table itself. They also allow to provide initial sorting values. **Properties work through the `v-model`**.

selection.title: Selection
selection.text:
Use the `selectable` prop to indicate whether the `va-data-table` should have selectable rows or not. The highlighting color of the selected row might be changed with the `selected-color` prop, passing a string with one of the possible color options: `'primary'`, `'danger'` and so on.

The selection may optionally be attached to a model with the standard `v-model` (using the `:model-value` prop and the `update:modelValue` event). This also allows to set the initial selection on the `va-data-table`.

pagination.title: Pagination
pagination.text:
Use the `per-page` and `current-page` props to enable pagination.

The `va-data-table` component is paginator-agnostic. I.e. it can work with any pagination component you'd like. In the example below, it uses both standard inputs and the `va-pagination` component.

styling.title: Styling
styling.text: Should be specified on columns (see the `columns` prop below). Allows to provide different values (`text-align`, `vertical-align` and `width` css properties, custom `class` and `style`) for headers and for columns' cells.

stickyHeader.title: Sticky header
text: The sticky header is set by the `sticky-header` property. Sticky header is achieved through CSS with `position: sticky`. This is NOT supported on all browsers. Check [caniuse.com](https://caniuse.com/?search=sticky)[[target=_blank]] before using this technique.

To work correctly, it is important to limit the height (set the value in the `height` property of the component or using the CSS `height` or `max-height` properties) of the table and assign a background color (set the CSS value `background-color`) of the table header.

other.title: Other
text: The component has many different properties, some of them are shown below with an example.
Example of `va-data-table` with **CRUD** actions using a `va-modal` component for editing each row:

uiElementGuide.title: UI Element Requirements
uiElementGuide.description: This page is intended for Vuestic UI contributors. It describes the requirements for the UI elements.

description.userExpectations: Components should be as user expects them to be. We achieve that by checking refs ([Vuetify](https://vuetifyjs.com)[[target=_blank]], [Quasar](https://quasar.dev)[[target=_blank]], [Ant Design](https://ant.design)[[target=_blank]], [iView](http://iview.talkingdata.com)[[target=_blank]], [Element UI](https://element.eleme.io)[[target=_blank]], etc.).
description.qualityComponents: Components should be of high quality. We achieve that by manually testing edge-cases and by early refactoring.

description.visualFeedback: **Visual feedback** - When a user interacts with a component they should see a result of their actions (could be implemented with :active selector or somehow else depending on the case).
description.keyboardNavigation: **Keyboard navigation** - You must ensure that UI elements are keyboard-accessible, and you must disable that functionality for elements that should not receive keyboard focus.

treeShakingRequirements.title: Requirements for Treeshaking
treeShakingRequirements.description: This page for contributors describes the basic rules and restrictions that need to be taken into account when developing for correct work Treeshaking.

about.title: How TreeShaking works

distFormats.esmSsr: esm-ssr - also used for tree-shaking, but uses {'@'}vue/server-side-renderer.
distFormats.iife: iife - used by browsers, can be included to page without bundler.
distFormats.cjs: cjs - used for bundlers that use CommonJS (e.g. node) format instead of ESM
distFormats.style: styles - SCSS utils, that is not required for components.

about.notice: We use Webpack for local development and rollup for build, so we have a special package to test this two things - bundlers-tests

requirements.title: Requirements and rules
requirements.esModules: We need to use ES module (esm format) and Named Exports (`export { somthing }` instead of `export default somthing`). Export default breaks tree shaking for importend file. It will fully loaded by bundler.
requirements.dependencies: TreeShaking works only with node modules, that is written in esm format. For example, we use `lodash-es` instead of `lodash`. That way we compile only functional we need instead of full library.
requirements.beforeBuild: Before release check dist with `bundlers-tests`. We need to check build with Webpack, Vite (Rollup) because vuestic-ui can work diffent for this two.

ampm.title: AM PM
ampm.text: You can specify `ampm` props if you want to use 12-hours clock format set as true or 24-hours clock set as false.

view.title: View
view.text: You can specify if time picker needs to show seconds and minutes.

filter.title: Filter
filter.text: You can hide specific time and user will not be able to select it.

timeInput.title: Time Input
timeInput.description: Time Input component is a combination of Time Picker and Input components. You can find usage examples using following links:

input.title: Parsing
input.text: Default parse time function likely cover all of your needs, but you can provide your own parse function using `parseTime` prop.
input.notion: It can parse such inputs: 11, 11:00, 11:00:00, 11 pm, 23, 2300, 11.00, 11somejunk00

format.title: Formatting
format.text: We format input text specific to `view` prop. You can pass custom format function that accepts Date and return string.

ampm.title: AM PM
ampm.text: VaTimeInput will automatically format input string if you need to use AM PM.

clearable.title: Clearable
clearable.text: The `clearable` prop adds a button to the right to clear the input. Prop `clearableIcon` sets the custom clear icon.

validation.title: Validation
validation.text: Validation works the same way as `VaInput` validation, except rules functions should accept `Date` instead of string.

colors.title: Colors
colors.description: Vuestic UI defines `CSS variables` of the colors that are used in your application. This allows you to easily build your selectors using the colors you specified in the [Colors Config](https://vuestic.dev/en/services/colors-config).
colors.customAlert: This is a custom alert that uses CSS variables.

syntax.title: Syntax
syntax.description: Vuestic UI uses the following syntax to organize `CSS variable` of the colors:
syntax.name: the name of the color specified in the Colors Config.
syntax.colorsUsed: Each default color of Vuestic UI  (including overridden colors) and the new custom color have their own `CSS variables`.

defaultColorThemes.title: Default color themes
defaultColorThemes.description: All the default colors of Vuestic UI are listed below:

reactivity.subtitle: Reactivity
reactivity.about: These variables reactive relative to `Colors Config`. This means that they will be updated when the configuration changes. Read more about how to update the configuration [here](https://vuestic.dev/en/services/colors-config#icon-config-service-api).
reactivity.additional: Please note that changing `CSS variables` of the colors directly, in turn, will not update `Colors Config`.

Arrows.title: Arrow buttons
Arrows.text: Arrow buttons allow user switch to next or previous slide.

Indicators.title: Indicator buttons
Indicators.text: Indicators (or dots) used to quicly change slide by it's index.

Slots.title: Slots
Slots.text: Slots allow you to customize carousel component.
